Input.threadtitle: Lectures 11 12. What is purpose of hopfield nets and Boltzmann machines?
Input.posts:
so I have watched lectures 11, 12. completed quiz 11. I kind of understand the algorithm and how to set all those bits, calculate energy, calculate probability of a certain configuration of units, etc. But what are we trying to achieve with all this? Is it just dealing with learning algorithms where inputs are binary and all units are binary? Does it somehow apply to learn to ,say, recognize digits? If so, how? there only some binary units keep changing to minimize some energy function. What is the purpose of this energy function? Does it represent something? like, how influential units are on one another? There was something mentioned about memory in lecture 11. but I feel it did not get clarified (or it just all mixed in my head) what it is remembering. Is it remembering some weights, for a particular configuration of binary units? It is all really confusing. P.S. In general, it would nice if the material was explained in a more simple, plain english. It seems that there is a wide specific dictionary in the topic of machine learning and it seems quite good to make us get used to it and be able to understand and use it. But it really gets in the way of truly understanding the material and introduces a lot of confusion.

So each unit has a bias and each pair of units has a weight. Both of these types of values can be negative, zero, or positive. If a bias is negative than all things being equal the unit wants to be off, if the bias is zero it doesn't care, if it is positive it wants to be on. If a weight is negative it doesn't want both units to be on, if zero it doesn't care, if positive it wants them both to be on. The absolute value of a bias or weight represents the relative strength of these desires. So the overall energy function is just the sum of these desires ($$\sum{b_iu_i} + \sum{w_{i,j}u_iu_j}$$) , and finding a global extrema of this function is finding the configuration of the units that satisfies the above desires the best. The remainder of the content is just essentially optimization/approximation strategy as the best known algorithm to directly compute the global best configuration has exponential complexity, and so is infeasible.

The most popular motivation is that such a model can learn to make interpretations of data: a data case gives rise to an internal representation, and with any luck, that internal representation is a rather meaningful one, which makes it easier to later do regression or classification on the data. The schoolbook example is that if you can learn a probability distribution over what creditcard transactions typically look like, then if you're the bank and you see a transaction coming in that has low probability under that model, it means that it's a really unusual transaction and you should investigate.

Input.threadtitle: Is there a theoretical proof that pre-training makes NN land in a better ravine ?
Input.posts:
Hi, objective function for neural nets is highly non-convex function. Seeking for better local optimum is the most important issue I guess. Many deep learning researchers argue that pre-training helps performance in a way that it makes us be able to find a better local optimum ( so it has better performance) However, I can't find a formal proof to support this idea. The most convincing mathematical proof I understand is $$p(v) = \Sigma_hp(h)p(v|h)$$ So when we freeze $$p(v|h)$$ and optimize w.r.t $$p(h)$$ we get a better log-likelihood for the data. However, I can'y see any relationship between that and 'finding a better local optimum in cost function space' any hints ?
